word.description:
{可樂} is a [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) for *cola* (the Mandarin pronunciation *kě lè* is pretty close), but in a punny way it also means *entertaining*.

{可} by itself is *able to* (but is generally used in {可以} for that meaning).

{樂} by itself is *music* (but more generally used in {音樂} for that meaning). So you can remember {可樂} as *can music*.

description:
[Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cola) soft drink. You would use this word when ordering a Coke (but there's another word specifically for Pepsi).

**Ordering**

{杯} is *cup* (or mug or glass) and is the [measure word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measure_word) for water (and other drinks), and {一} is *one*, so to order a glass of cola, ask for 一杯可樂 (yāt būi hó lohk in Cantonese, yī bēi kě lè in Mandarin), *one cup of cola*.

word.description: This word combines two [loanwords](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) -- {檸檬} is a [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) for *lemon*, and {可樂} is (and sounds like) *cola*, so 柠檬可乐 is *lemon cola*.

images.place: Lucky House Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: [Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cola) soft drink with slices of lemon.
{健} is *healthy*, {怡} is *pleasure*, and {健怡} is *cola*, so 健怡可樂 is *healthy pleasure cola* (which sounds more enticing than just *diet cola*).

word.description: {百} is *hundred*, and {事} is *thing*, so you can remember {百事} as *hundred things*.

images.place: Dim Sum Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: The Cantonese for [Pepsi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pepsi) is *baak sih*, which sort of sounds like *Pepsi* (the Mandarin pronuncation *bǎi shì* is further off). Technically, it's short for 百事可樂, Pepsi-Cola (baak sih hó lohk), but as in English, people usually don't bother saying the full name (and which is why in Hong Kong, I would order Pepsi more often than Coke because I found the Cantonese for *Pepsi* easier to say than the Cantonese for *cola*).
